title: How six fit young men were left disfigured and fighting for lives after 'Elephant Man' drugs trial
text:

Eleven years ago, eight fit young men agreed to take part in a routine drugs trial at a London hospital in exchange for £2,000. 
Signing up to the trial, the volunteers believed it was a chance to make easy money and to help potentially revolutionise cancer treatment. 
At worst, they thought they may suffer a splitting headache or nausea - that would pass within a couple of hours of receiving the drug. 
But instead, six of them were left writhing, vomiting and screaming in agony as their temperatures soared and their organs began to fail. 
Fighting for their lives, some of the human guinea pig saw their heads swell like balloons, while several had to have body parts amputated. Six men were left fighting for their lives after receiving the drug, TGN1412 (Photo: BBC) One of the men writhes around in his hospital bed after receiving the drug (Photo: BBC) Read More Touching photos show 'twin who died in womb watching over brother as he grows up without him' 
One victim’s girlfriend later said he looked like "the Elephant Man". 
As the TGN1412 drugs trial spiralled into one of Britain's most infamous medical emergencies, shocked medics battled to save the young men. 
Fortunately, they suceeded. 
A few weeks later, five of the volunteers were released from hospital. 
However, the youngest participant, Ryan Wilson, then 21, had to spend four months in hospital after suffering heart, liver and kidney failure. 
He also experienced frostbite-like effects that led to sections of his feet being amputated and some of his fingertips falling off. 
Now, a BBC documentary retells the story of the clinical catastrophe - which came to be known as the "Elephant Man" trial - and the volunteers involved. Ryan Wilson experienced frostbite-like effects that led to some of his fingertips falling off (Photo: Channel 4) Medics battled to save the young men as the situation spiralled into a medical emergency (Photo: BBC) Read More Mum's fury after tot's chicken pox pictures used by Facebook scammers who claim he has cancer for 'likes' 
The programme, which airs tonight, features candid personal testimony from doctors who struggled to bring the "mysterious" situation under control. 
One medic remarks: "This was a mystery, we had no way of predicting how severe it was going to get. There was no rule book for how to deal with this." 
It also features comment from investigators who were tasked with discovering what went wrong with the drugs trial on March 13, 2006. 
At the time, there were concerns the drug could have been tampered with, leading the volunteers to suffer horrific and life-changing side-effects. 
And it looks at the impact of the trial on the patients themselves. 
One participant reveals: "I thought I was doing something good for science, but in the end it was the worst thing I could ever have done." Participant David Oakley, who appears in a new BBC documentary, suffered excruciating back pain (Photo: BBC) Ryan had to spend four months in hospital after suffering heart, liver and kidney failure (Photo: BBC) Read More 
The trial was carried out at a private unit at Northwick Park Hospital in north-west London run by Parexel, a US company that helps pharmaceutical and biomedical companies develop and launch their products. 
TGN1412 was intended to treat leukaemia and chronic inflammatory conditions. 
Although it had never been tested on humans, it had been successfully tried out on monkeys - so medics were hopeful about the outcome. 
Because the eight volunteers, aged between 19 and 34, had signed up to a Phase 1 trial, they were to become the first people to try the drug. 
Of them, two were given a placebo. 
The participants, who all knew there were risks involved, were given an 11-page consent form to fill out ahead of the trial, the Daily Mail reports. 
In exchange for receiving the drug - developed by a German company - intravenously, they had been offered £2,000. The clinical catastrophe came to be known as the "Elephant Man" trial (Photo: BBC) The trial was carried out at a private unit at Northwick Park Hospital in north-west London run by Parexel (Photo: BBC) 
"Medical trials were like a get-rich-quick-scheme," explains participant Raste Khan, then a 23-year-old graduate. "A no brainer." 
But within an hour, the six volunteers who had not received the placebo were left vomiting, fainting and screaming in pain. 
"It was all manic, everything was happening all at once," says Raste, who was then unaware that he had received a placebo. 
"They were vomiting, they were screaming in pain, people were fainting, they couldn’t control their bowels... it was like a horror movie." 
The patients, who all received the drug on the same day, were immediately transferred to intensive care, where doctors battled to save their lives. 
Meanwhile, their horrified families were told their loved ones may be about to die, according to the documentary, called The Drug Trial. Participant Raste Khan was not aware that he was one of the two people who received a placebo (Photo: BBC) 
Rob Oldfield, who was one of the six men affected, previously told the BBC how he was rushed to intensive care at around midnight. 
At about 2am, his mum was told to come to the hospital. "The doctors were saying this is your goodbye perhaps - this person could die," he said. 
Although Rob and the five others survived, they were left worrying about how their health might be affected in the future by the trial. 
Indeed, the potential long-term effects on their immune systems are not known. 
Some of the participants have since received compensation from Parexel. 
The Medicines & Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency produced a report in April 2006 following the disaster, which made headlines across the world. Rob Oldfield, who also took part in the trial, says he was rushed to intensive care at around midnight (Photo: BBC) 
Soon after, the Health Secretary established a group of leading international experts to look into what could be learned from the trial. 
In December that year, the group's report was published, with 22 recommendations to improve the safety of future Phase 1 trials. 
These included that independent expert advice is needed before a high-risk study, and that volunteers cannot all be tested in the same day. The Drug Trial: Emergency At The Hospital airs today (Tuesday, February 21) at 9pm on BBC Two Like us on Facebook
